paragraphs.content: A Facsimile from the Book of Abraham
paragraphs.contentHtml: A Facsimile from the Book of Abraham

paragraphs.content: Fig. 1. The Angel of the Lord.
paragraphs.contentHtml: Fig. 1. The Angel of the Lord.

paragraphs.content: Fig. 2. Abraham fastened upon an altar.
paragraphs.contentHtml: Fig. 2. Abraham fastened upon an altar.

paragraphs.content: Fig. 3. The idolatrous priest of Elkenah attempting to offer up Abraham as a sacrifice.
paragraphs.contentHtml: Fig. 3. The idolatrous priest of Elkenah attempting to offer up Abraham as a sacrifice.

paragraphs.content: Fig. 4. The altar for sacrifice by the idolatrous priests, standing before the gods of Elkenah, Libnah, Mahmackrah, Korash, and Pharaoh.
paragraphs.contentHtml: Fig. 4. The altar for sacrifice by the idolatrous priests, standing before the gods of Elkenah, Libnah, Mahmackrah, Korash, and Pharaoh.

paragraphs.content: Fig. 5. The idolatrous god of Elkenah.
paragraphs.contentHtml: Fig. 5. The idolatrous god of Elkenah.

paragraphs.content: Fig. 6. The idolatrous god of Libnah.
paragraphs.contentHtml: Fig. 6. The idolatrous god of Libnah.

paragraphs.content: Fig. 7. The idolatrous god of Mahmackrah.
paragraphs.contentHtml: Fig. 7. The idolatrous god of Mahmackrah.

paragraphs.content: Fig. 8. The idolatrous god of Korash.
paragraphs.contentHtml: Fig. 8. The idolatrous god of Korash.

paragraphs.content: Fig. 9. The idolatrous god of Pharaoh.
paragraphs.contentHtml: Fig. 9. The idolatrous god of Pharaoh.

paragraphs.content: Fig. 11. Designed to represent the pillars of heaven, as understood by the Egyptians.
paragraphs.contentHtml: Fig. 11. Designed to represent the pillars of heaven, as understood by the Egyptians.

paragraphs.content: Fig. 12. Raukeeyang, signifying expanse, or the firmament over our heads; but in this case, in relation to this subject, the Egyptians meant it to signify Shaumau, to be high, or the heavens, answering to the Hebrew word, Shaumahyeem.
paragraphs.contentHtml: Fig. 12. Raukeeyang, signifying expanse, or the firmament over our heads; but in this case, in relation to this subject, the Egyptians meant it to signify Shaumau, to be high, or the heavens, answering to the Hebrew word, Shaumahyeem.
